top_comment.text:
Whatever the official stance regarding China(s) may be, I've heard it said 
that there are, de facto (which neither knows nor cares about Beijing's 
decree) actually FIVE Chinas. the People's Republic of China (aka Mainland 
China, capital city Beijing), the Republic of China (aka Taiwan (island's 
proper name is Formosa), capital city Taipei), the sovereign city-state of 
Singapore, and two quasi-independent jurisdictions which while officially 
considered part of the PRC, are treated by Beijing with a "hands-off" 
policy and which are both former European colonies: Hong Kong (formerly a 
colony of the United Kingdom), and Macau (formerly a colony of Portugal). I 
would put the latter two in a sort of gray area that's neither fully 
sovereign nation nor "part of mainland China" either. And technically China 
and Taiwan both consider themselves to be THE Chinese government WITH 
jurisdiction of BOTH mainland China AND the island of Formosa, similar to 
how both North and South Korea consider themselves to be the ONLY Korea. As 
for my claim of there being "five Chinas", that's how most economists 
actually consider things to be at present since each of them has an economy 
that's completely separated from all of the others.﻿

comments.text:
Your definition is "de facto independance", which is never used as the 
criteria for deciding what is and isn't a country. Is the newly declared 
Islamic State a country? Hardly. It may have a degree of control & 
authority over a certain geographical area, but they aren't a country. In 
fact, ask them if they think they're a country and they will tell you, 
"There are no countries, only Islamic State! World is Islamic State & 
Islamic State is World!"

So quite obviously your definition isn't very useful. As CPG said, "What 
makes a country a country is if other countries think that country is a 
country." That might sound confusing but by going by that method we can 
determine what is and is not a country.

Take Kosovo. According to Serbia, Russia, China and some others Kosovo is a 
rebellious Serbian province but according to USA, the UK, France and much 
of the western world Kosovo is independent. Now despite the fact that it 
should probably be an Albanian province, Kosovo is in fact a country. 3 out 
of 5 UNSC members (including the most important one) along with 107 UN 
member states say that Kosovo is a de jure state, thus, despite not being a 
UN Member state, Kosovo is a de jure state.

Northern Cyprus on the other hand, despite having de facto control over 
it's claimed territory, only one UN member state, Turkey, recognizes it and 
the UNSC says that it does not exist. Thus, it is a fiction of Turkish 
imagination.

comments.text:
+J Ó Dálaigh Truth told.  My family has our origin in southern China like 
some three hundred years ago.  You can tell from my family name.  But 
Taiwan has been separated from China politically since 1895. 

As for the short four-year window of 1945-49 after WWII when Taiwan was 
occupied by the ROC army, it was the only exception when Taiwan and China 
were actually under the same regime, while at the same time ROC was 
being challenged in China by the communists, a fight which it ultimately 
lost. 

The military occupation did not constitute legitimate sovereignty transfer 
of the island from Japan to China, nor has that imagined transfer ever 
happened between the two countries.  As a matter of fact, in all post-WWII 
treaties Japan signed, it only says that Japan gives up the sovereignty 
of Taiwan permanently, and says nothing about to whom that 
sovereignty shall be transferred.  Therefore, it's mean and right so 
to say from 1945-1990 Taiwan's sovereignty was actually held among the 
Taiwanese people, and the ROC regime never through any due process 
attempted to claim it, until the 90s.

Through a series of political reformation of democratization and 
localization, the ROC government's legitimacy to rule in Taiwan was 
finally confirmed as the congressional and presidential elections 
occured in the 90s, during which ROC has also lost its so-called "legitmate 
representation" of China.

Hope all this is made clear.

Yes, we still have a constitution that was written in China in 1947, and 
although it has been revised several times for the past two decades, it 
still needs some more definitive terms to better describe and define our 
country.  But the fact that we have it, different from China's current PRC 
constitution, I think, is the most valid proof that Taiwan (ROC) and China 
(PRC) are two different countries.

comments.text:
No, I am not from Texas. Only been to Texas a few times. A nice state, but 
not my home. And yes, I have seen his video on whether or not Texas could 
secede from the Union. He references that the Supreme Court ruled that 
states are not allowed to secede from the Union. This ruling was made after 
the Republican Party took control of the Supreme Court some time after the 
Civil War. Immediately prior to the Civil War, when South Carolina was 
threatening secession (for the second time), President Buchanan asked the 
Supreme Court if 1) states were allowed to secede from the Union and 2) he 
was allowed to use force to keep them in the Union in the case they did 
secede. The Supreme Court answered that states were allowed to leave the 
Union and he was not allowed to use force to keep them in the Union. So 
basically, the Supreme Court ruling that CGP Grey references was made after 
the fact and was made in complete contrast to a previous Supreme Court 
ruling, even though they never overruled it. So, technically, there is one 
Supreme Court ruling saying states can secede and another one that says 
they cannot secede. So, the way I approach the issue is that there is no 
reference in the Constitution to secession, and the 10th Amendment says 
that "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, 
nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States 
respectively, or to the people", so therefore it would be legal, as the 
Constitution does not specifically ban it, so therefore it would be an 
issue which is up to the States and their people. If they wished to leave 
the Union, they would be allowed to.

Yes, it did ultimately lead to the end of slavery, but the reasons it was 
ended aren't quite what most people think. Most people tend to think of

in the Union, waged a war of aggression against the Southern states by 
claiming it was a "civil rebellion" and justified his blockades of Southern

I'm not saying Davis was much better. Only differences between him and

comments.author: DOE MAN

comments.text:
Slavery really wasn't the main issue of secession. Part of Lincoln's 
campaign platform was based on ensuring that the Southern states could keep 
their slaves. He was no abolitionist. He was, in fact, extremely 
racist. Hell, he even founded the country of Liberia as an attempt to get 
rid of as many of the free black people as possible. The Republican Party 
didn't give a rat's ass about whether or not the Southerners held slaves, 
they just wanted to keep it out of the West. And Virginia was given back 
the land it ceded to form DC in 1846, which is well before they started 
even threatening secession. Now granted one of the reasons they wanted it 
back was so they could have an extra pro-slavery county in the state so 
that abolitionists wouldn't gain a majority in the Virginia General 
Assembly, but that was only one of many reasons. The biggest reason they 
wanted it back was because the city of Alexandria (which is the main city 
in the area that Virginia ceded to Washington DC) fell into a major 
economic decline due to neglect from Congress. To find the causes of 
secession, let's look at the first state to leave the Union,
South Carolina. During the Nullification Crisis (which was over tariffs), 
South Carolina threatened to secede from the Union. To explain it very 
basically, a tariff was passed and all the Southern states were not very 
happy and South Carolina went so far as to declare the tariff null and void 
within their state. The federal government then offered a compromise 
by lowering the tariff. Most of the Southern states accepted this because 
they didn't want any kind of confrontation, but South Carolina still felt 
it was unacceptable, so they raised their militia to ensure that the 
Federal government could not enforce the tariff in the state and threatened 
to secede. So another compromise was offered, greatly reducing the tariff, 
and South Carolina accepted and backed down from their threat and allowed 
the tariff to be enforced. One of the main points of Lincoln's campaign was 
to pass an even higher tariff than the ones that caused the Nullification 
Crisis. They had threatened to secede if the tariff was passed, and when 
Lincoln was elected, they knew he wouldn't listen to them, so they seceded 
from the Union, and they were followed shortly by Mississippi, Florida, 
Alabama, etc. The Southern economy relied heavily on trading with foreign 
nations and the tariffs would have completely crippled their economies.

comments.text:
+C. Caner Telimenli
I understand your desire to be precise.

An empire is just a nation that controls foreign nations is it not ?

*Vikings*
To be fair to the Vikings they were traders, explorers, settlers and not 
just barbaric raiders as Hollywood would have us believe. 
They had high tech seafaring knowledge and they certainly ventured far 
across the world. Denmark ruled a section of the UK called Danelaw as a 
direct result of attacking London. (London bridge was not falling down, it 
was being pulled down by Longships).
Iceland, Greenland and the Faroe Islands are also Danish.
Maybe the Vikings did not have an empire because they did not have a centre 
ruler as such, other than the gods. I was just throwing it out there 
because it was a very influential movement of people. The UK is still full 
of Viking DNA and place names.

(Come to think of it, who were not raping and pillaging in that dark period 
of history ?)

*Economic Systems*
I consider the modern day economic system to be primitive. Trade is trade 
is it not ?
As for money, or one currency, most nations used the same currency of gold 
or silver coins. Maybe that is too early in the monetary system to use for 
or against the topic.

*Empire Definition*
If the definition of Empire is to dominate the immediate area then England 
did not have an empire as they did not command South Ireland. Unless you 
were referring to their own immediate country of England.
Then there is the grey area of when did the English empire start. When the 
Romans came or left, after Danelaw, after the Magna Carta, after the fall 
of Scotland etc.
That also complicates the topic.

What of the Roman Empire and the Vatican Papal States ?

I'm not sure that domination of the immediate area can count for the 
definition.
Has every empire not been contested by its own native "rebels" in one form 
or other ?

*Christians*
I was referring to the entire history of Christianity so yes, Crusades, 
exploitation of wealth, influence all across Europe and the Americas, the 
ethnic cleansing under the guise of the Witch Trials etc.
They have a central power base, conquered many nations by using fear 
propaganda, military force, infiltration and assimilation of foreign 
cultures, making laws and banking systems across their domain etc.

*Jews*
Jews certainly have a reputation for infiltration, money and law control 
throughout history so they also have credibility for being jerks on a 
global scale. That is why I added them to the list. Not sure what their 
power centre is but it is far reaching.

As Christianity, Muslim and Judaism come from the same roots I'm not sure 
we can just label that under Arab. Also Arab is not a country or single 
movement of people. Like the Celts, or Vikings, they are more tribal 
orientated and come from several geographical locations.


I'm just exploring the topic, if we learn something then that is a bonus :)
comments.author: planetwalker

comments.text:
Hey, so apparently you haven't done much research on this but instead 
simply rely on selective news sources to be reliable (ignorance is bliss, 
eh?). Perhaps you've heard of Hamas? If not I'll give you a little info on 
this group: it's a terrorist organization that's dedicated to the 
destruction of the state of Israel. Of course you might be one of those 
people who doesn't think Israel is a legitimate state, and if that's the 
case nothing I say further will matter to you at all.

If you're not one of those people then please read on. Hamas is an 
organization whose charter dedicates the group to the destruction of Israel 
and the raising of Allah over every inch of Palestine (Israel, the Gaza 
Strip, the West Bank, and Jerusalem). Look it up, it's in their charter. 

Simply glancing at the news or Wikipedia searching the Palestinian/Israeli 
conflict isn't going to give you the whole picture. You'll see footage of 
dead Palestinian children and the startling difference of Israeli and 
Palestinian casualties and initially think: "Israel is a monster!!". Trust 
me, I thought the same thing when I first started looking into this issue.

Unfortunately that would be placing the blame where the blame is not due. 
Yes, it's true, Israel fires missiles upon towns, and sadly people die. I'm 
not going to to try sugar-coating it, it's terrible. But that doesn't 
automatically mean Israel is the villain.

Before going on I have a question for you: if you were the leader of a 
country and you were under attack by missile fire from a terrorist 
organization, what would you do? Negotiation won't work, these people just 
want to see you dead. So what is there to do? Retaliation, no?

This is the case we find in Israel. Hamas fires missiles upon Israelis from 
highly populated areas of Palestine. Why? Because they don't care about the 
people living in those towns, all they care about is destroying Israel. In 
fact, Hamas purposefully fires missiles from Palestinian towns, schools, 
mosques, etc, because they WANT Israel to retaliate. Why? Because it makes 
Israel look bad.

Condemning Israel for doing what any other country would do in this 
situation is not the response. Especially since Israel has been actively 
pursuing a two-state solution with Palestine since 1948. Israel does want 
peace. But they're not going to just stand by when missiles are fired upon 
them from those dedicated to their destruction.

after having to suffer colonialism that most analysts are fairly sure they 
would accept sanctions if it meant reunification. The Taiwanese Strait is 
also one of the most militarised coastlines in the world.

top_comment.text:
Perhaps interesting to note, the world holds a set of four criteria a 
nation has to fulfil of they want to even begin being called a nation. It's 
explained within the Treaty of Montevideo, and these criteria are quite 
high quality, for they include Vatican City but leave out Hong Kong. Now, 
these criteria are the following:
1. A territory. Basically, a piece of land. Or part of an oil rig. Or the 
local McDonalds. Pretty much every piece of walk-able land can be claimed 
as territory, and this is probably the easiest to fulfil. This makes 
impossible the 9gag Empire due to lack of territory. 
2. A people. The Dutch, the English, Dixies, Yanks, Brazilians, the Muslim 
community... You basically need a number of people to live in your nation. 
This, of course, stops Sealand from being a country, with her population of 
1. You need some more to actually claim to be a nation.
3. Real Government Control. This is a very tricky bit, because this is 
where many would-be nations fail. They need control over their citizens, 
the ability to make laws and enforce those laws. This, for instance, begs 
the question if the central government in Somalia is the government of a 
country at all, if their control doesn't reach beyond the doors of the 
parliament. 
4. Ability to engage in foreign affairs. Now, this is the single most 
important criterium for this video. Can a nation engage in foreign affairs? 
Does it have the capabilities to do so? It doesn't matter if other nations 
actually engage in these affairs, does a nation have the capability? This 
makes the important distinction we need in the video. Let's take Vatican 
city as an example, as well as Hong Kong.
Does VC have a territory? Yeah, VC. It even has a wall around it.
Does VC have a people? Yeah, Italians, Swiss, and Catholics. She can make 
the claim.
Does VC have a real government with control? Oh yeah. A king, a pope, 
absolute royal authority... You bet she has. 
Does VC have the capability to engage in foreign affairs? Yes, she does, 
and she uses it a lot to go on tour and all. 

Now, for HK.
Does HK have a territory? Yeah, HK. It even has a sea around it.
Does HK have a people? Yeah, Brits, Chinese, the whole shabang. Some even 
call themselves Kongers. Or is it just me?
Does HK have a government? Yes, they even fight about it like in every 
civilised nation. Check.
Does HK have the capability to engage in foreign affairs? No. She doesn't 
have a foreign ministry, that is left to China. So, according to these 
criteria, HK is not a country, while VC is. Hurrah for international law!﻿
top_comment.author: Bo Salomons

comments.text:
You forced too hard, the trips that the Pope makes around the world are 
hardly a sign of capacity of "engaging in foreign affairs", HK dudes can go

comments.author: Vitorruy1

comments.text:
Going to have to call bullshit on your fourth criteria re: Hong Kong.  For 
one, not having a specifically formal foreign ministry doesn't preclude a 
nation from having the CAPABILITY to engage in foreign affairs.  If Canada 
were to dissolve its foreign ministry (let's just say rampant corruption 
was exposed or something) and we decided to just have our Prime Minister, 
or hell, Frank the Janitor pop next door to America as a representative to 
talk to Obama, are we not "engaging in foreign affairs"?  What would you 
qualify as a "foreign ministry" able to conduct these affairs?  How about 
"...At present, the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Offices under the 
Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in countries that 
are the major trading partners of Hong Kong...serve as the official 
representative of the Government of the Hong Kong SAR in these countries 
and international organisations. Its major functions include facilitating 
trade negotiations and handling trade related matters, inter-government 
relations with foreign governments; the promoting of investment in Hong 
Kong; and liaising with the media and business community."

Hong Kong engages in its own foreign relations all the time.  "...China had 
to accept some conditions such as Hong Kong's basic law before its return. 
The basic law ensured Hong Kong will retain its own currency (the Hong Kong 
Dollar), legal system, parliamentary system and people's rights and freedom 
for fifty years; which means that the agreement will end in 2047. This 
agreement had given Hong Kong the freedom to functions as its own country 
instead of a part of China...In accordance with Article 151 of the Basic 
Law, Hong Kong concluded over 20 agreements with foreign states in 2010 on 
matters such as economic and financial co-operation, maritime technical 
co-operation, postal co-operation and co-operation on wine-related 
businesses.".  Sure as hell sounds like they're functioning as a country to 
me.  So what's this about hurrah for international law?
comments.author: Billy Calder

top_comment.text:
193 full UN Members + 2 Observer States = 195 countries so far.

Vatican City supposedly isn't a member, but considering the Holy See is 1 
of the 2 Observer States I think I already covered Vatican City. (The 
difference between Vatican City and the Holy See is basically semantic, 
except for dates. Vatican City was founded in 1929, whereas the Holy See 
was founded by Saint Peter in the 1st Century. I don't really feel like 
talking about all the bizarre technicalities already in 1 of Grey's other 
videos, so I'll leave this here.)

So, we have counted 195. (The other Observer State is Palestine.) Add in 
Kosovo (which has an ethical right to be recognized no matter who currently 
doesn't recognize it, seeing how its people were treated as a former 
Serbian province), and Taiwan (which is obviously capable of appointing its 
own diplomats no matter how loudly China whines about it), and 195 + 2 = 
197.

By my calculations, there are currently 197 countries on Earth to be exact.﻿

comments.text:
Specifically, an insult that distracts from the actual substance of the 
argument is an Ad Hominem. Calling someone a "fucktard" randomly in the 
street with no debate going on (maybe you think he fucked your girlfriend 
or something) isn't an Ad Hominem, but in this case you appeared to be 
distracting from an actual argument, so then it would be.

Which other territories do you mean? South Sudan already has UN membership. 
Chechnya was treated badly by Stalin, but Stalin died in 1953. Kosovo was 
the subject of a much more recent Serbian genocide.

Many of the territories you're thinking of have not drawn up declarations 
of independence in their provincial or territorial legislatures, something 
Kosovo has done. If no declaration of independence has been drawn up, there 
is nothing for pre-existing countries TO recognize in terms of independence 
for that territory even if they wanted to do so. Once a 
provincial/territorial legislature declares independence from the parent 
country, countries can choose to recognize that or not, but only then of 
course.

system, borders, etc. and yet no recognition (I'm a Native South American). 
The UN has a complete monopoly on global affairs because they run an agency 
called ISO. Without approval from ISO a country cannot have internet 
access, use telephones to make international calls, send or receive mail or 
packages to other countries, or appear on world maps. This is because ISO 
make the standards for everything, and refuse to allow non-UN members

top_comment.text:
I'd disagree: A country is any self contained people with clear 
distinctions from another place. A country is a country when the people 
within it's defined borders say it is. For example, Tibet is it's own 
country. It's people say it is its own country. Just because China still 
thinks it own's Tibet because of historical conquests doesn't mean they do. 
The same goes for any country that is asserting it's independence. 

I analogize this to families. When do you become independent from your 
family? Either when you chose to, or when that family chose for you. When 
you leave home and assert your independence you are no longer intrinsically 
part of your former family. You're an individual on your own. This doesn't 
mean your family ceases to be your family, just as a country's origin 
country doesn't cease to be that, but you are a separate entity. 

In a similar sense when a US state secedes from a larger state to become 
it's own state it becomes independent of that initial state. It is up to 
the people (while no longer a viable option for current states). 

How the world around the new country perceives them should be irrelevant. 
Unfortunately because of the UN and it's rules, some countries find it very 
difficult to attain their world nationhood...this still doesn't dismiss 
their independence and claim to be a country. ﻿
top_comment.author: Krist Martin

comments.text:
I'm Taiwanese too (my family has been there for generations--over a 
century, and I have some aboriginal blood).  What I find odd, is that 
Taiwan has its own currency, laws, political system, passports, health care 
system...none of which have changed in the last few decades, and none of 
which looks anything like the PRC's.  Still, Taiwan was more widely 
recognized as a country in the 80s and 90s than it has been in the last 
decade, as China's gained economic and political power--essentially 
bullying other countries to at least stay silent on Taiwan's status. Kind 
of funny that the status of one country/territory/place (Taiwan) can be 
called into question based on the fluctuating power of another country 
(China)...(but as this video illustrates, that happens all the time, given 
that whether the UN recognizes a country is based on the opinions of a few 
select countries...)

In any case, glad that Taiwan was brought up in this video!

top_comment.author: happylatvian

comments.text:
+theonlylampshade  The reason the UK is an exception is because the 
institution has been stable for centuries (longer than probably any other 
institution on the planet), so whoever wields a portion of the power has 
managed to make it work. Off the top of my head, I certainly cannot name 
another country whose institutions have gone unchanged for so long.

The UK model doesn't fit with everyone else in the world though (at least 
not yet), which is why we see so many nations that have adopted it (former 
British colonies where the majority of the population at the time of 
establishment are not British descendants) struggle to maintain that same 
stability and efficiency.

Do remember that governing as a republic is still a very novel reality; 
throughout most of world history, the empire was the model most 
nation-states followed. In China's case, governing as a republic is only a 
century old, and governing as a stable republic is only 65-years-old at 
most. We cannot expect it to be the exception that the UK's government has 
become.
comments.author: ZhangtheGreat

comments.text:
+ZhangtheGreat I'd disagree; in the United Kingdom we have the balance 
about right. Unlike the US we rarely have lameduck governments, and unlike 
Europe our governments are nearly always single party majorities. This 
means our governments are quick to respond (or at least always able to), 
especially Conservative governments which tend to concentrate on doing the 
job, rather than making people happy. Getting them a reputation as the 
'nasty party', but the more competent one. Labour are also able to quickly 
respond, though they have a problem with wanting to please people - meaning 
they look friendlier, but their policies make far less sense. 

As you point out the CCP isn't particularly united, and I would actually 
assert that our major political parties in the UK are in many ways more 
united. We the electorate may slam them, but they do often act as one in 
the national interest.
comments.author: theonlylampshade

comments.text:
+theonlylampshade It's a trade-off: do you want responsiveness or do you 
want representation? Political science says you cannot have both: a 
government that has the power to quickly respond can't be forced to spend 
all its time listening to the opinions of everyone who has one. Similarly, 
a government that is representative will act significantly slower because 
of the need to give everyone a voice.

The PRC system, with the right people in charge, is highly efficient. 
Tthat's why it's able to enact new policy so quickly (with no example 
better than how rapidly its economy has grown in the last 3.5 decades).

Believe it or not, the CCP isn't as unified as it presents itself. If you 
study how it operates a little in depth, you'll see that within the party 
itself, cliques and factions strive for control. Basically the CCP operates 
more like a multi-party coalition system than it does as a single-minded 
unit.

comments.text:
Political science lesson time! There are two forms of "independence": de 
facto and de jure. De facto independence concerns who really is in charge. 
De jure independence concerns who is "rightfully" in charge. According to 
the definition of de facto independence, Taiwan is a country. According to 
the definition of de jure independence, it's not...except in the eyes of a 
few countries around the world (at least officially)...because most of the 
world officially recognizes Taiwan as a territory of the PRC even though 
the PRC has never controlled it.

quantity it was produced in, due to mechanical and industrial evolution - 
bearing in mind that cotton growth in India post war increased 
exponentially - but didn't require and increase in available manpower due 
to the mechanical advances. Also, had we had the Dixie cotton available, we 
could have kept production in India to food, rather than letting them 
switch to Cotton in an attempt to get more money - and those hundreds of 
thousands would not have starved to death the way they would.

I also don't think Apartheid would have happened in the south. I think that 
the black population of Dixieland would have dropped hugely at the 
end/after independence, as hundreds of thousands of slaves see it as their 
last chance for freedom and run to the Union (who would definitely receive 
them readily) and the southerners would be in little position to stop them 
as they try to set up a nation. Secondly, after liberation - can you 
imagine the levels of emigration? It would be HUGE, also I think you may 
agree that many of the remaining black would have been colonised to British 
Africa (as the British did with their own freed British slaves) to help 
diffuse tension between free blacks and whites post slavery. I see it as 
much more plausible that the Civil Rights movement - rather than being a 
counter to the racist movements born out of the deliberate humiliation of 
the southern people - would have been a slower, drawn out process from post 
WW1 into the 21st Century. rather than a surge in the 60's/70's.

comments.text:
In the United Nations, the US, China, France, Russia and the UK (the 
victorious great powers of World War 2) are considered permanent members of 
the UN Security Council. As such, they both are never voted off of the 
Security Council but also have a "veto" power. Any proposal in the UNSC 
must have a majority vote but because of the veto power, only one of those 
5 countries above must vote no, and regardless of the unanimity of the 
proposal, it won't happen.

captions.text: # How Many Countries are There?
How many countries are there?

Easy: just grab a map and start counting,
yes? No.

Not all maps are created equal -- borders
will differ depending on who you got the map
from.

So if individuals disagree, then surely a
committee will save the day. Go to the United

Nations, find the room where countries sit
-- each with a little name tag -- start counting

and get an answer. Now of course, countries
come and countries go, but at the time this
video was made the answer is 193.

Fastest video ever, right? Except: you know
this isn't over. The United Nations list is

less a complete class roster than a club membership
that doesn't include everyone.

Take, Vatican City who is a country but is
too cool for school when it comes to being
a member of the United Nations.

And while Vatican City's exact situation is…
complicated he's straightforward compared

to other non-United Nations countries… or
places -- the terminology is going to have
a be a bit, unclear here.

Take Kosovo, who want's to join the UN club,
but membership requires none of these five

countries to reject you. And while the United
States, The United Kingdom and France think

Kosovo is a country, Russia and China think
she's just a rebellious part of Serbia and

so veto her membership. As for everyone else,
just over half recognize Kosovo as independent

and Kosovo, adorably, has a website where
she thanks each one in their own language.

But Kosovo, is not there only other… place
that wants to be considered a real country.

There's Transnistria, Nagorno-Karabakh Republic,
Abkhazia, and South Ossetia. Which might,

or might not, be part of Moldova, Azerbaijan
or Georgia depending on who you ask. Two of

these… countries, no UN members recognize
as countries, and other two have only five

supporters. Though all four of these... places
recognize each other as countries. There's

also The Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic
and Northern Cyprus each with their own supporters.

At this point you might be thinking 'OK, srsly,
what's the deal? I don't care who these guys

think are countries, are these places countries
or not?' If I fly to one for a Holliday, will

it *look* like a country when I get there?
The answer is, 'maybe'.

These... countries are all autonomous, to
some extent, with governments that issue passports

though these may be of rather limited use
and depending on which ones you're visiting

they may have more or less control of the
territory they claim as theirs. You won't
always find a clear border.

What makes many of these places... fuzzy is
they're *usually* born of conflict in the
recent-ish past.

That answer is probably less helpful than
you want so think of it like this: while The

United States is clearly a country now, in
1776, not so much. Then she was just an idea

in minds of rebel scum. She wasn't recognized
as a country instantly and without diplomatic

effort to change that Young America would
never have made it on her own. Much like what

happened a century later when she got her
own rebel who, unlike elder sister, failed
in the diplomacy department so… yeah.

And so it goes today with many of the maybe
countries in the world. Maybe they're future

United States and maybe they're future Confederacies
-- but in the moment it's hard to say -- because
these things can take decades to settle.

By the way, these maybe-countries are super
awkward for countries to deal with. While

your tiny island nation might not want to
get involved in the affairs of distant lands

you still have to decide to send a diplomat,
or not -- meaning even inaction forces you

to pick a side in *every territorial skirmish
in the world*.

A notably awkward case being: Taiwan… errr,
sorry, Chinese Taipei which is *totally* part

of China and no one would ever think otherwise…
Is China gone?

OK: by any reasonable definition, Taiwan is
a separate country and has been for years,

but China won't let go and insists you call
her Chinese Taipei and don't forget who makes

all your clothing and utensils and TVs and
phones and computers and everything.

So almost all countries -- including the mighty
United States -- plays along even though they

unofficially acknowledge Taiwan's independence
and do things that wouldn't make any senses

otherwise -- like sending aircraft carriers
to protect one part of China from another
part of China.

Thus the innocent question 'how many countries?'
has led us straight to a big 'World War III:

Press Here to Start' button which is getting
depressing so lets move on to...
Ohhhh, right.
::sigh::

No more politics: on to higher ideas: The
Olympics. Surely from their perch among the

gods they have a disinterested view of the
countries below. "How many are there, Olympics?"
Two hundred and four? Huh.

So Olympics is a bit… special. She defines
Puerto Rico as a 'country' even though it's

unambiguously part of the United States as
well as Bermuda and Aruba which are connected

to the UK and The Netherlands along with a
bunch of other places that are happy to play

in her Olympic Games as Nations but make no
claims to independence.

Presumably, Olympics includes these to bump
up the number so she can say 'more than 200

countries compete!' Though even her inflated
list doesn't include Vatican City -- because,

given his demographics, divine intervention
would be required to take home a gold.

And Vatican City brings us right back to the
core of the difficulty with this question:

a consistent definition of 'country' is impossible
because your checklist needs to both include

Vatican City the least country-like country
that's still a country -- and that also exclude

the Anti-Vatican City: Hong Kong: -- the most
country-like country that isn't.

Also don't forget from previous episodes the
seemingly endless territories which look and

act like independent countries, but just sort
of aren't.

And this isn't even brining up the various
Nutters who plant a flag on an Island, or

an oil rig, start printing currency on their
fancy inkjet and declare Deludtopia a new
nation.

So with no checklist to follow where does
that leave us? The best answer to the question

'how many countries' for the forceable future
is probably to say 'around 200' and leave
it at that.

An answer with more significant figures implies
more agreement than there really is -- because

ultimately, what makes a country a country
is if other countries think that country is
a country.
